actor.summary: counting tweets @Gnip/@TwitterBoulder. previously counted phonons @CUBoulder || mostly made of ☕️

body:
RT @heddle317: Improving diversity does not mean lowering the bar.

https://t.co/wbVwKTIgb0 https://t.co/c9FWPiQP1W

urls.expanded_url_description: It's 2015. Technology companies are feeling enormous pressure to hire more diverse employees. In an effort to increase these diversity metrics, they decide to do the unthinkable: they lower their hiring bar. However, since diversity is still a relatively new thing in the industry, hiring managers are unfamiliar with what a diverse candidate even looks like. This is what leads to their fatal mistake. They accidentally hire...a zombie. This zombie is the worst possible zombie a tech company can imagine. Instead of killing people and eating brains, this zombie underperforms and kills the morale of its teammates. The "bad employee" virus spreads through the company like wildfire and soon, everyone is doing nothing of value. The engineering team starts putting out a prolific amount of low-quality code. Bugs are increasing exponentially. Users are having issues and no one is solving them. The platform is hemorrhaging customers by the minute. The company's value plummets and finally, the worst part of the worst-case scenario happens: the company goes under and is forced to merge with the Canadian government to become a public service. But it doesn't stop there. The tech industry starts collapsing, and another bust is upon us. Companies fall, one after the other, and even the impenetrable brogrammer castle that is Uber is not spared this deadly virus. Marc Andreessen would be tweeting about how this wasn't the result of a bubble, but he, too, has been infected and his account is eerily quiet. Much like the first dot-com crash, the highways are all empty. Twitter is silent, and the tech industry is completely out of unicorns to blog incessantly about. All because one tech company chose to lower the bar in the name of diversity.
urls.expanded_url_title: Improving Diversity Does Not Mean Lowering the Bar

Improving diversity does not mean lowering the bar.

body: The Structural Integrity ep of @99piorg is not only a fantastic piece of storytelling...  https://t.co/ROHNd99FXw

urls.expanded_url_description: 99% Invisible is honored to accept a 2015 Third Coast International Audio Festival award for Structural Integrity, a story of architectural engineering gone wrong, and then covertly made right. When it was built in 1977, the 59-story CitiCorp Center had a potentially fatal flaw that could have caused the building to collapse during a sever storm, and take out the entire Midtown Manhattan skyline with it. This flaw (and the plan to fix it) was so secret, that even the person who found the problem only discovered the full story decades later.
urls.expanded_url_title: 110- Structural Integrity (Rebroadcast) — 99% Invisible

object.summary: The Structural Integrity ep of @99piorg is not only a fantastic piece of storytelling...  https://t.co/ROHNd99FXw

body: This article has a helpful discussion (+interactives) of how to think about p-values and false discovery rates https://t.co/k1qCRebJxa

urls.expanded_url_description: If the p -value is <.05, then the probability of falsely rejecting the null hypothesis is < 5%, right? That means, a maximum of 5% of all significant results is a false-positive (that’s what we control with the α rate). Well, no. As you will see in a minute, the “false discovery rate” (aka. false-positive rate), which indicates the probability that a significant p -value actually is a false-positive, usually is much higher than 5%. You have a p-value of .01. Is the following statement true, or false? You
urls.expanded_url_title: Felix Schönbrodt's website

object.summary: This article has a helpful discussion (+interactives) of how to think about p-values and false discovery rates https://t.co/k1qCRebJxa
